metadata.title: Unreal and spurious correlations | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Real or Spurious (Cor)Relations: Attractive People You Date Are Nastier
metadata.description: Use Python to simulate data, improve data science skills, learn causal inference, and determine if attractive people have nastier personalities

all_paragraphs: Here’s a common intuition: You’ve been picking your dates really carefully based on how good they look and whether they have great personalities. But somehow, among the people you’ve gone on dates with, those who are more attractive tend to have worse personalities. There’s a strong negative correlation between attractiveness and personality.

Before you conclude that attractive people must be nasty, we can use some basic data science skills to test our intuition and see if something’s gone horribly wrong (spoiler: yes, something is wrong).
If you enjoy causal inference problems and paradoxes like this one, check out Lord’s Paradox (another common inference problem):

But how do we know if the negative correlation between attractiveness and personality is real? Data scientists deal with correlations regularly, and a good way to gain more intuition about the data and learn analysis methods is via simulation. So let’s simulate some data to test our intuition.
First, let’s import the common data science modules: numpy, pandas, and seaborn (for visualizing simulation results).

Let’s specify a few simulation parameters and simulate some data. We’ll set a random seed so you can replicate my results, but you can skip it if you prefer. Your simulations will work too but your results won’t be identical to mine, but they’ll be very similar.
Since personality and attractiveness are randomly generated using np.random.randn(), the simulated values are drawn from normal distributions and the two distributions aren’t expected to correlate.

Now let’s specify your dating criterion. This parameter reflects how picky you are. We’ll set it to 0.80, which means you’re going to date only people whose combined attractiveness and personality values are the top 20th percentile in your pool of 500 potential dates.
Now let’s decide who you actually go on a date with.
Filter the data so it contains only people you dated.
The dateddataframe has 100 rows (you can verify with dated.shape). Of the 500 people you could potentially date, you dated 100 of them (the top 20th percentile).

Let’s plot the correlation between the personality and attract features of the people you dated. Remember, you’d chosen your dates based on how good they look good (‘attract’) and whether they have great personalities (‘personality’).

Assuming you’ve used the same random seed as me earlier on, the correlation between attract and personality should be about –0.48, which you can verify by using the pandas .corr() method: dated.corr()
Also, if you regularly fit statistical models in Python, I highly recommend the Pingouin library.

Good data scientists understand chance and probability very well. The negative correlation above might be all due to chance, so it’s always essential to run multiple simulations to see if we can repeat the results above.

To avoid repeating code (DRY principle in software development— don’t repeat yourself), let’s define a function that runs simulations. We’re basically taking all the code above and putting them inside a function.
Things to note in our newly-defined simulate function below:

Below is the histogram of 1000 correlation values from 1000 simulations. The midpoint of the histogram is about –0.65 and all your simulated correlations are smaller than 0. That is, in all 1000 simulations, the correlations were negative: The attractive people you dated had worse personalities!

What if the negative correlations were because of our simulation parameters? Now, let’s instead assume you have a smaller pool of people to choose from (300) and you decide to be more lax with your dating criterion (0.7: you’re willing to date people who are above the 0.7 quantile).
Again, all our simulations had negative correlations (about –0.60) between attractiveness and personality.

Do you think the negative correlation is real or spurious? That is, do attractive people really tend to have worse personalities, or is there something wrong with the nature of the data we’re dealing with? Spoiler: It’s the latter, but I won’t tell you why (because the answer can be found in the data), other than tell you it’s a causal inference problem.

Before you conclude, play with and tweak the code above, simulate more data, and change the parameters (or even the code itself). Crucially, plot your simulated data and results in different ways and you might see interesting patterns in the data.

I look forward to your thoughts, comments, or answers below. If you’ve enjoyed this article, follow me for more data science articles and I’ll explain how causal inference can help us solve this (cor)relation problem in future posts!
